text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with black lentil soup
that's right whenever i have bacon and
black lentils in my kitchen at the same
time something very similar to this soup
usually happens and while black lentils
are not used as often as green lentils
to make this
I think these black lentils really make
a better soup although I shouldn't say
better I should say different and what
makes it different it's better but we'll
talk more about that later for now let
me just show you how to put this
together so we're gonna put a soup pot
on medium heat with just a little bit of
vegetable oil at the bottom and we're
gonna toss in some sliced up bacon and
what we're gonna do is we're gonna cook
that fairly crisp all right you do not
want to start a soup with flabby bacon
so the rule of thumb here is I want you
to cook that until it looks and smells
so good you consider not making soup and
just eating the bacon like that when it
gets to that point it's done and once
that's done we're going to go ahead and
dump in our aromatic vegetables our
onions celery carrots also known as
mirepoix
pardon my french and we'll also toss in
a nice big pinch of salt and then what
we're going to do is we're going to
sweat those vegetables on medium for a
good while all right we want those
vegetables to soften and sweet a little
bit so I really don't want you to rush
this step and by the way do not skip
that pinch of salt we want to draw out
some moisture from those vegetables so
that bacon does not cook any further and
you know I hate to give times but this
is probably going to take about 10
minutes or so so just keep cooking
stirring occasionally until those onions
turn translucent and get a little bit
golden brown around the edges those
carrots are going to darken up so that
looks to be perfect right around there
and at this point we're going to season
it up a little bit with some freshly
ground black pepper some ground cumin
some dry thyme and then last but not
least a little bit of cayenne we'll go
ahead we'll give those a quick stir and
then it's time for the star of the show
the black lentils also known as Beluga
lentils check them out they're so pretty
so we'll go ahead and we'll add our
lentils to the pot and I'm not sure why
exactly I'd like to coat the lentils in
this bacon fat an aromatic vegetable
mixture but I do so I'm gonna give that
a stir till they're all coated and at
that point we are ready for our stock or
broth so I'm gonna go ahead and pour in
some chicken broth and if you're
wondering can I substitute vegetable
stock instead well before I answer that
let me ask you if you remember adding
the bacon earlier but sure I guess if
you're not going to use the bacon you
can use vegetable stock here would I be
disappointed oh yeah
quite a bit but anyway we're going to
add our stock stir that in at this point
I want you to turn your heat to high
because we want to bring this up to a
simmer and while we're waiting we're
going to go ahead and add a bay leaf
some people add bay leaves to every soup
recipe I don't but with lentil soup bean
soups I really do like it and then like
I said we're going to bring this up to a
simmer on high heat and then once it's
simmering go ahead and back your heat
down to low and we're just going to let
that simmer for about 45 minutes to an
hour or until you think your soup is
done all right but don't go out for a 45
minute to an hour jog you got to keep an
eye on this because you may have to add
more liquid so this is what might look
like after a half hour and I'm
definitely going to add another splash
of broth all right I want this thick but
I still want it to be soup so I'm gonna
go ahead and stir in some chicken broth
I want to maintain a certain viscosity
something right about there and then all
we have to do is keep this simmering
until those lentils are perfectly tender
and we're happy with it
and again I'm guessing 45 minutes or an
hour or something like that so I simmer
in mind for about 15 more minutes or so
and it looked like this but you can't go
by looks grab a spoon and let's taste so
the first taste was for lentil
tenderness oh and they were perfect and
then the second taste is for seasoning
and I decided I needed a little more
pepper a little more Cayenne a little
more salt so I'm gonna give that one
final taste and once we've determined
our soup is seasoned perfectly we're
gonna go ahead and finish up with a
little bit of freshly chopped to tell
you parsley and at that point we can go
ahead and switch to a ladle because this
soup is done and I mentioned earlier I
like the black lentils better than the
green for this and you can see here as
I'm dragging the ladle through why all
those little individual black lentils
retain their integrity even when cooked
tender so while the soup has a very
heavy thick look it does not have a very
heavy thick mouthfeel it's actually
rather light it's just a very
interesting phenomenon and why I think I
prefer the black lentils but anyway
we're going to go ahead and ladle that
up and I'm thinking we'll finish with a
little more extra parsley I'm also going
to finish this with a little tiny
drizzle of our very best extra-virgin
olive oil it's going to add a little
extra flavor and richness and also give
the appearance a little bit of bling do
people still say that probably not if I
am but anyway there you go our black
lentil soup is done so easy and it's
just incredibly delicious yes the bacon
helps but most of it is those beautiful
blue goo lentils and by the way I want
to mention if you do upgrade to the
premium package we're going to throw in
a little bit of sour cream dice
an extra Cayenne again that's only if
you upgrade to the premium package and
yes I did steal that garnish idea from
black bean soup which this sort of
reminds me of and as good as it was I'm
not sure oh he has more French it was
also delicious tricked out like this but
either way this is just a great
delicious and relatively healthy soup so
I really do hope you give this a try
head over to food whooshes calm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
